auth:logout.description: clears local login credentials and invalidates API session

auth:token.description:
outputs current CLI authentication token.
By default, the CLI auth token is only valid for 1 year. To generate a long-lived token, use heroku authorizations:create

auth:whoami.description: display the current logged in user

client-secret.name: client-secret
client-secret.description: secret of OAuth client to set

config:edit.description:
interactively edit config vars
This command opens the app config in a text editor set by $VISUAL or $EDITOR.
Any variables added/removed/changed will be updated on the app after saving and closing the file.
examples:
# edit with vim
$ EDITOR="vim" heroku config:edit

# edit with emacs
$ EDITOR="emacs" heroku config:edit

# edit with pico
$ EDITOR="pico" heroku config:edit

# edit with atom editor
$ VISUAL="atom --wait" heroku config:edit

remote.name: remote
remote.description: git remote of app to use

config:get.description: display a single config value for an app

shell.name: shell
shell.description: output config vars in shell format

config:unset.description: unset one or more config vars
examples:
$ heroku config:unset RAILS_ENV
Unsetting RAILS_ENV and restarting example... done, v10

$ heroku config:unset RAILS_ENV RACK_ENV
Unsetting RAILS_ENV, RACK_ENV and restarting example... done, v10

git:clone.description: clones a heroku app to your local machine at DIRECTORY (defaults to app name)
git:clone.examples:
$ heroku git:clone -a example
Cloning into 'example'...
remote: Counting objects: 42, done.
...

remote.name: remote
remote.description: the git remote to create, default "heroku"

git:clone.example:
$ heroku git:clone -a example
Cloning into 'example'...
remote: Counting objects: 42, done.
...

git:remote.description:
adds a git remote to an app repo
extra arguments will be passed to git remote add
git:remote.examples:
# set git remote heroku to https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    $ heroku git:remote -a example

    # set git remote heroku-staging to https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    $ heroku git:remote --remote heroku-staging -a example

remote.name: remote
remote.description: the git remote to create

git:remote.example:
# set git remote heroku to https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    $ heroku git:remote -a example

    # set git remote heroku-staging to https://git.heroku.com/example.git
    $ heroku git:remote --remote heroku-staging -a example

remote.name: remote
remote.description: git remote of app to use

local.description:
run heroku app locally
Start the application specified by a Procfile (defaults to ./Procfile)
examples:
$ heroku local
$ heroku local web
$ heroku local web=2
$ heroku local web=1,worker=2

pipelines:add.description:
add this app to a pipeline
The app and pipeline names must be specified.
The stage of the app will be guessed based on its name if not specified.

remote.name: remote
remote.description: git remote of app to use

stage.name: stage
stage.description: stage of first app in pipeline

pipelines:connect.description: connect a GitHub repo to an existing pipeline

repo.name: repo
repo.description: the GitHub repository to connect to

pipelines:create.description:
create a new pipeline
  An existing app must be specified as the first app in the pipeline.
  The pipeline name will be inferred from the app name if not specified.
  The stage of the app will be guessed based on its name if not specified.
  The pipeline owner will be the user creating the pipeline if not specified with -t for teams or -o for orgs.
